Docs.summary: Represents a request for notification for a given command.

remarks.format: ## Remarks This class provides low-level access to the query notification services exposed by SQL Server 2005. For most applications the <xref:System.Data.SqlClient.SqlDependency> class provides a simpler way of using query notifications. However, if you need fine control over when notifications occur, or you need to customize the message data returned as part of a notification, the <xref:System.Data.Sql.SqlNotificationRequest> class is the one to use.

remarks.format: ## Remarks If the default constructor is used to create a <xref:System.Data.Sql.SqlNotificationRequest> object, that instance must have its <xref:System.Data.Sql.SqlNotificationRequest.UserData%2A> and <xref:System.Data.Sql.SqlNotificationRequest.Options%2A> properties initialized before assigning the object to a <xref:System.Data.SqlClient.SqlCommand> object's <xref:System.Data.SqlClient.SqlCommand.Notification%2A> property. The default values used by the constructor are NULL (`Nothing` in Visual Basic) for the <xref:System.Data.Sql.SqlNotificationRequest.UserData%2A>, an empty string for the <xref:System.Data.Sql.SqlNotificationRequest.Options%2A>, and zero for the <xref:System.Data.Sql.SqlNotificationRequest.Timeout%2A>.

Docs.value: that contains the SQL Server 2005 Service Broker service name where notification messages are posted and the database or service broker instance GUID to scope the server name lookup.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The value of the <xref:System.Data.Sql.SqlNotificationRequest.Options%2A> property has the following format:
`service=<service-name>{;(local database=<database>|broker instance=<broker instance>)}`
For example, if you use the service "myservice" in the database "AdventureWorks" the format is:
`service=myservice;local database=AdventureWorks`
The SQL Server Service Broker service must be previously configured on the server. In addition, a Service Broker service and queue must be defined and security access granted as needed. See the SQL Server 2005 documentation for more information.

Docs.summary: Gets or sets a value that specifies how long SQL Server waits for a change to occur before the operation times out.
Docs.value: A signed integer value that specifies, in seconds, how long SQL Server waits for a change to occur before the operation times out.

remarks.format: ## Remarks After the time-out period expires, the notification is sent even if no change takes place. The <xref:System.Data.Sql.SqlNotificationRequest.Timeout%2A> property defaults to the value set on the server.

Docs.exception: The value is less than zero.
